I.  THE PROPOSAL  
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $14,200,000 to Sylvan Agriculture Limited (SAL) for the Second PRAN Agribusiness Project 
in Bangladesh.1 
 
2.  The project will support SAL’s expansion into potato chips, potato flakes, and pasta 
through the financing of new food processing facilities. SAL will procure potatoes under contract 
farming arrangements and provide secure income to 2,000 smallholder farmers. Given the high 
poverty reduction impact at farming and factory levels, the project will promote inclusive business. 
ADB engaged with SAL to achieve effective gender mainstreaming in the project. SAL will commit 
to a gender action plan (GAP), an improvement over ADB’s first financing to SAL which included 
only one gender target. The project is also fully aligned with the Government of Bangladesh’s 
goals to enhance agricultural productivity, increase local value addition, and create jobs. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. Agricultural development is crucial to eradicating poverty and 
creating conditions for sustainable and equitable growth in Asia, where a large proportion of 
people still rely on agriculture for their livelihoods. Empirical studies have shown that agricultural 
investment is one of the most effective and least-cost strategies to reduce poverty and hunger.2  
 
4.  Bangladesh remains an agrarian economy, with agriculture providing nearly half of all 
employment and supporting more than 70% of the population.3 While its share in gross domestic 
product dropped to 15% in 2017, agriculture still constitutes the main source of income and food 
security for most Bangladeshis, particularly the poorest.  
 
5.  Agriculture in Bangladesh is plagued by issues such as being highly unorganized, with 
fragmented landholdings and inefficient value chains. Consequently, value addition in the sector 
remains extremely low—leading to substantial post-harvest losses and a high degree of reliance 
on intermediaries for farmers. This is exacerbated by lack of access to good quality inputs, 
finance, extension services, and other infrastructure on small farms, which leads to low yields. 
This continues to prohibit farmers from accessing markets. 
 
6.  To increase value addition in the sector, develop commercial agriculture, and connect 
farmers  to  markets,  private  sector  investment  is  critical.  Formal  value  chains  are  typically 
developed by corporate buyers, who integrate vertically to source directly from the farm gate, to 
secure long-term access to quality products. Contract farming is one such tool whereby the private 
sector can help farmers obtain access to quality inputs, best agronomic practices, and most 
importantly provide a direct market linkage, making the value chain more efficient.  
  
                                                
1  The first PRAN Agribusiness Project was approved in 2012 (ADB. 2012. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Sylvan Agriculture Limited for the PRAN Agribusiness Project 
in Bangladesh. Manila). SAL and ADB signed a $25.1 million loan in 2012 and $4.8 million was outstanding as of 30 
June 2018.  
2  Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, World Food Programme, and International Fund for 
Agricultural Development. 2012. The State of Food Insecurity in the World. Rome. 
3  ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Bangladesh, 2016–2020. Manila.

2   
7.  The PRAN-RFL Group (PRAN), one of Bangladesh’s largest food and agribusiness 
groups, has been developing farmer engagement through contract farming since the 1990s. 
[Redacted] The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has an existing relationship with the group, with 
an outstanding loan to a group company, SAL (footnote 1). SAL was incorporated in 2012 when 
PRAN wanted to undertake manufacturing of (i) starch and liquid glucose, (ii) flour, and (iii) frozen 
food products. SAL applied for ADB assistance to finance the construction and operation of three 
new facilities for these products, although the project scope was later changed to include only 
starch and liquid glucose. For its starch and liquid glucose production, SAL initiated contract 
farming with cassava farmers to procure raw material. As of 2018, about 2,500 cassava farmers 
supply SAL directly for its operations. Given ADB’s association with SAL, PRAN approached ADB 
to finance SAL’s current expansion to pasta production and potato processing, for which SAL will 
continue to procure from contract farmers.   
 
8.  Project design. The project will support the construction of a manufacturing plant and the 
purchase of machinery and equipment to produce potato chips, potato flakes, and pasta. The 
plant will be located in Habiganj Industrial Park, in the north-eastern part of Bangladesh, where 
the starch and liquid glucose plant is also located. The project will promote inclusive and 
sustainable agricultural value chains with higher local value addition of farm produce. 
 
9.  The project will source potatoes from 2,000 contract farmers. Most of the farmers will be 
from the Dinajpur district, in the northern part of Bangladesh. SAL will enable farmers’ access to 
a high-yielding and higher-value variety, especially suited for processing,4 helping them to move 
from low-income-generating subsistence crops to commercial agriculture (cash crops). SAL has 
about 20 field staff to advise and train farmers on best agronomic practices and guide them 
through the agricultural production process. Farmers also get access to agricultural inputs such 
as fertilizers and pesticides to grow potatoes of good quality.5 SAL will adjust the cost of 
agricultural inputs, which are provided on credit at the time of sowing, against the total amount 
payable. As part of the contract arrangements, SAL will provide a buy-back guarantee based on 
the market price, providing the farmers with a guaranteed source of income.  
 
10.  Potato farmers engaged with SAL are expected to benefit from increasing income levels, 
as in the case of cassava farmers. 
 
11.  The project will add value to local farm produce and boost the local agribusiness industry 
with the new food processing facilities.  
 
12.  Sponsor. PRAN is one of the largest manufacturing groups in Bangladesh—the market 
leader in food products under the PRAN brand and in plastics under the RFL brand. The late 
Amjad  Khan  Chowdhury  founded  the  group  in  1981  as  a  small  agricultural  equipment 
manufacturer. It has since evolved into a conglomerate with 34 companies, 13 of which are in the 
food industry. [Redacted] 
 
13.  PRAN has extensive experience in the food industry.  
 
14.  PRAN  is  one  of  the  largest  private  employers  in  Bangladesh,  with  some  95,000 
employees. Workers receive training and all factories have day-care facilities. Most workers are 
                                                
4  SAL uses the courage variety of potatoes, which are less prone to infestations and provide a better yield than other 
locally used varieties such as diamant, cardinal, and granola. 
5  PRAN agricultural staff advises farmers on practices for integrated pest management and encourages the use of 
biological alternatives to chemical applicants, where possible.

3 
unionized. PRAN engages contract farmers to ensure consistent supply volume and quality and 
to reduce dependence on imports, allowing PRAN food products to have 90% local content. 
 
15.  SAL’s shareholding structure has changed since ADB’s initial financing in 2012 following 
the demise of its founder, the majority shareholder at the time, in July 2015.  
 
16.  Integrity due diligence was conducted.6 No significant or potentially significant integrity 
risks were identified. Tax integrity due diligence was not required. 
 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Output 
 
17.  Impacts. The project will contribute to at least three of the government’s priorities for the 
agriculture sector in Bangladesh, as stated in the Seventh Five Year Plan, FY2016−FY2020.7 
These include (i) facilitating increased private sector investments in agriculture and improving the 
agro-processing value chains; (ii) linking farm produce with the market to overcome the issue of 
low prices of products at the farm, low investment in agriculture, and inadequate credit support to 
farmers; and (iii) shifting, where feasible, to higher-value crops for commercialization. 
 
18.  The Seventh Five Year Plan stresses the need to build capacity in agriculture to ensure 
remunerative prices for produce, both to maximize rural income-generating opportunities and to 
optimize the use of limited natural resources. The plan also calls for small and marginal farmers 
to be supported in selling their products by developing linkages with domestic and international 
markets. The project achieves this impact through its contract farming feature, which will ensure 
that farmers are offered ready market access toward a stable income opportunity. 
 
19.  Outcome. The project’s outcome will be the increased production of potato chips, potato 
flakes, and pasta, leading to improved rural livelihoods. The project will effectively promote 
inclusive growth, as potatoes will be directly sourced from 2,000 contract farmers. It will also 
create direct employment for about 450 people, at least 50% of whom will be female. New factory 
workers will benefit from well-paid jobs, as in existing SAL facilities.8  
 
20.  Output. The project’s output will be the food processing plant completed and operational. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations   
 
21.  Consistency  with  ADB  strategy  and  country  strategy.  Strategy  2030  identified 
promoting rural development and food security by supporting agriculture (improving value chain 
linkages; and increasing agricultural productivity, food security, and food safety) as one of the key 
operational  priorities  linking  ADB  operations  to  inclusive  growth.9 The  proposed  project  is 
consistent with this strategy as it (i) supports the development of agricultural value chains 
connecting  agricultural  production  to  food  processing;  and  (ii) increases  productivity  by 
introducing new higher-yielding crop varieties, which lead to increased incomes for farmers. 
Strategy 2030 also calls for support to inclusive business models. The project will provide

economic opportunities to contract farmers and factory workers, who are predominantly from the 
base of the income pyramid. Therefore, the project is classified as inclusive business (para. 31).  
 
22.  The country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for Bangladesh identified improving rural 
livelihoods by increasing the productivity of agriculture as among the priority investment areas for 
projects since agriculture provides nearly half of all employment and supports more than 70% of 
the population (footnote 2). It also stated that ADB will continue to provide financial assistance to 
private sector projects with sound fundamentals and strong development impact. 
 
23.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is aligned 
with ADB’s Operational Plan for Agriculture and Natural Resources as it supports agribusiness 
investment and value chain development including production, processing, distribution, and 
consumption.10 The plan states that investments in agriculture and natural resources are essential 
to promoting inclusive growth, reducing poverty, and promoting environmental stability. It also 
mentions that the Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) will continue to be among those 
entities responsible for implementing the plan. The project has met the key elements for PSOD 
investments as identified in the plan, which are strong sponsors from a credit perspective and 
best practices for implementation. The project is also consistent with ADB’s sovereign operations 
in Bangladesh. The ADB South Asia Department has a proposed pipeline project of $100 million 
in 2020 for a water project with an agricultural value chain component to assist farmers to 
strengthen production. To prepare this project, a transaction technical assistance (TA) project in 
2019 will explore opportunities to engage agribusinesses using contract farming models (such as 
PRAN) and to invest in related rural infrastructure and post-harvest facilities.

G.  Unique Features 
 
24.  The project is ADB’s first repeat nonsovereign assistance to a borrower in the agribusiness 
space. Given the high poverty reduction impact at the contract farming and factory levels, as 
validated by the independent poverty impact assessment,11 the project is classified as inclusive 
business. The project will create 450 well-paid factory jobs (footnote 8) in the Habiganj district, 
where the share of households living below poverty threshold (poverty rate) is 25%. The project 
will also boost the income of 2,000 contract farmers (para. 10) and provide livelihood opportunities 
to 24,000 temporary laborers in the Dinajpur district, where poverty rate is 38%.12

5 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
25.  ADB proposes to provide a loan facility of up to $14.2 million to SAL, which will use the 
loan proceeds to finance its expansion into potato processing and pasta production. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  ADB assistance will add value in several fronts: 
(i)  Long-term funding. ADB will provide long-term US dollar funding, which is not 
readily available in Bangladesh. SAL has access to short- and medium-term local 
currency financing from local commercial banks to fund its working capital needs. 
However,  capital  expenditure  projects  need  to  be  funded  through  long-term 
financing given a longer payback period.  
(ii)  Safeguard best practices. ADB will promote higher environmental and social 
standards through compliance with its safeguard policy requirements. Similar to 
the arrangement for the existing loan, ADB’s proposed assistance to the new 
project will ensure that these policy requirements are also applied to the new plant. 
(iii)  Gender inclusion. ADB will promote gender equality through a GAP.  
 
C.  Risks 
 
[Redacted] 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
27.  Safeguards. ADB has categorized the investment in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category B), involuntary resettlement (category 
C), and indigenous peoples (category C).13  
 
28.  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and 
the  institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  SAL  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and 
environmental  impacts  are  deemed  adequate.  Key  environment  safeguard  issues  during 
construction include solid and liquid waste disposal, noise and vibration, and occupational health 
and  safety.  During  operation,  relevant  areas  of  concern  include  air  emissions,  wastewater 
discharge, solid waste disposal, workers’ health and safety, food quality assurance, and resource 
efficiency and conservation. An external expert prepared an initial environmental examination, 
which includes an environmental and social management and monitoring plan. The external 
expert conducted an environmental and social compliance audit, with a corresponding corrective 
action plan, for the potato chips component. SAL has established a grievance redress mechanism 
to handle project-related grievances. SAL’s institutional capacity and commitment to manage the 
project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed adequate.  
 
                                                
13 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

6   
29.  The project will not entail physical or economic displacement, as the project land is owned 
by SAL within the Habiganj Industrial Park. The project will not affect any indigenous peoples. 
 
30.  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), SAL has incorporated measures to promote gender equality in its business.14   
 
31.  Other social aspects. SAL will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s 
Social Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized 
core labor standards.15 The client will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ 
compliance with such laws and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation 
with affected people will follow ADB requirements.16 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
 
32.  SAL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations  
 
[Redacted] 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
33.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),17 
ADB  will proceed with the  proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of 
Bangladesh has no objection to the proposed assistance to SAL. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the 
proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$14,200,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Sylvan Agriculture Limited for the Second 
PRAN Agribusiness Project in Bangladesh, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
 
19 November 2018
